awd_titl_txt: Mathematical Knowledge for Equitable Teaching: Exploring opportunities to enable Elementary pre-service teachers to develop ambitious and equitable teaching practices in both face
awd_abstract_narration:
Researchers, at the University of Houston, are designing, implementing and studying a curriculum that prepares preservice, elementary teachers for equitable teaching of mathematics.  The program increases the mathematical knowledge of preservice teachers and helps them recognize and implement equitable instruction.  The preservice teachers are learning to recognize equitable practices by using the Mathematical Quality and Equity Observation Protocol (MQE) to assess teaching as viewed in video cases.  The program includes mini courses of one hour that are spread throughout the program, ending just prior to student teaching.

Building on prior NSF-funded research, the researchers are investigating ways to help preservice teachers of mathematics at the elementary level to learn the mathematics needed for teaching and how to provide equitable instruction that encourages all students to share their mathematical thinking.  Based on data collected in this exploratory study, researchers will revise the MQE and improve the validity and reliability of the instrument.  They are also developing ways to use the MQE for both assessment and for instruction.

The materials, curriculum, and model produced by this project are helping elementary teachers learn important mathematics and learn to teach that mathematics in an equitable way.  Although the model includes mini courses that are taught throughout the program, the materials can easily be adapted to a longer, traditional course for preservice teachers.  The revisions of the MQE are producing an observational protocol that has the potential to vastly improve the way researchers study teachers' instructional practices.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Summary

NSF DR K-12 Proposal 1725551: Mathematical Knowledge for Equitable Teaching Project, PI: Dr. Imani Goffney, University of Maryland-College Park

The Mathematical Knowledge for Equitable Teaching Project, an exploratory project, addressed the teaching strand; it was designed to develop and study curricula for use in elementary teacher preparation programs to help prepare elementary teachers for the ambitious and equitable teaching of mathematics to linguistically and culturally diverse students. It also revised and refined an instrument, titled Mathematical Quality and Equity (MQE) Observation Protocol, designed to measure the degree to which teachers provide access to mathematics content for diverse learners.  

Mathematical Knowledge for Equitable and Ambitious Teaching Curriculum

The MKET curriculum is an elementary mathematics methods course that focuses on preparing pre-service teachers for ambitious and equitable mathematics teaching with a deliberate lens on working with linguistically and culturally diverse students in ways that promote justice and students' development of a positive mathematics identity. The approach for the development of this curriculum rests on the idea of deliberate and simultaneous attention to issues of equity, justice, and mathematics for designing lessons, activities, and learning experiences for teacher candidates. One aspect of this work has been to consider how the revised curriculum could be used to strengthen EC-6 teacher preparation programs, in particular, the program at the University of Houston where the first version was designed and piloted. Later, the PI, Dr. Imani Goffney, changed institutions moving to the University of Maryland-College Park where Dr. Goffney has continued to tweak the design of the MKET curriculum and worked to modify the structure of the curriculum based on what was learned in prior iterations of the course, for efficiency and with an eye for preparing for dissemination.

To continue to study the impact of the MKET intervention course on early career teachers, Dr. Goffney applied for and was awarded a fellowship from the Greater Texas Foundation. In this work, Dr. Goffney follows a small sample of teachers (n=7) to study and evaluate the implementation of the MKET course on early career teachers. This work continues to produce usable information about which aspects of the MKET curriculum are most useful for new teachers which provides information to Dr. Goffney about how and when to emphasize different aspects, tasks and activities.

Mathematical Quality and Equity Observational Rubric

Another goal of the project was to revise and refine an observational instrument designed to measure equitable mathematics instruction. An MQE Validation workshop was hosted with team of expert educators where the goal was to ensure that Dr. Goffney?s MQE observational rubric measures principle constructs of equitable mathematics teaching and to ensure the validity and reliability of the MQE observational instrument. Results verified the reliability and validity of the MQE Observational Rubric. Additional analyses and manuscript development are in progress.

Contributions of the MKET Project

Core aspects of our project have important impact on the field of mathematics education and mathematics teacher education. The MQE observational tool is a novel and unique instrument. Preliminary research and collaborative work indicate that as a theoretical set of constructs and measurement tool is are of interest and of use to the mathematics education community. We will continue to conduct quantitative and qualitative analyses to better understand the measurement potential for the MQE observational tool. Additionally, the MQE observational tool also serves as a type of framework for equitable and ambitious teaching practices. Each individual code represents a domain of teacher knowledge and skill that is essential for instruction that creates access to rigorous mathematics content for culturally, socially, and linguistically diverse students.

Additionally, it is important to acknowledge that attention and considerations for equity, systemic racism, structural oppression, and other related topics are unevenly taught in K-12 public and private schools, in institutions of higher education and even in mathematics education doctoral programs, therefore projects like MKET are vitally important and necessary. As many teacher preparation programs across the country are investigating ways to center justice and equity in the curriculum and program, aspects of our project, both the MQE observational tool and central components in the MKET curriculum, are important resources. Results from our project offer evidence that particular teaching practices support teacher candidates with developing both mathematical knowledge and skill that are central for promoting social justice and equitable access to mathematics for their future students. Most recently, the instructors for the other methods courses (reading/ ELA, science, social studies) have begun to consider the applicability of aspects of the MKET intervention course approach when making revisions to their courses. In particular they are focused on the deliberate efforts to simultaneously address the development of teaching practices, attention to equity and social justice, and disciplinary content in a methods course.

Note: I'm grateful for the support of the late Dr. Karen King and NSF to this project.
